column1: #Text=—The tradesmen of this town have agreed to entirely suspend business on Monday and Tuesday next.
#Text=—The Committee of Council on Education have presented a favourable report with regard to these schools.
#Text=—Our market on Saturday last presented a perfect picture, and was crowded with those articles required for the sustenance of man at the approaching festive season.
#Text=High prices were demanded, and of course paid.
#Text=—Two concerts were given on Tuesday in aid of the funds for the erection of a new organ in the church of the neighbouring parish of Bradford.
#Text=Webber, the Misses Oram, and Miss Vinnicombe, professionals, from Taunton, assisted, and the result was tbe addition of £40 to tbe funds.
#Text=The pony he was driving ran away and upset the cart, throwing him and his youthful son to the ground.
#Text=Pyne was seriously iujured, and also sustained a com. pound fracture of one of his legs.
#Text=His son fortunately escaped with a few slight contusions.

#Text=Gunn, the talented master of our School of Art, is endeavouring to get up a concert on a grand scale in aid of the funds of the Taunton and Somerset Hospital, which are at present at a somewhat low ebb.
#Text=We need scarcely say that we wish him every success, more especially when we consider the object is that of the relief of the sufferings of the poor and distressed.
#Text=Harring. ton, a native of South Carolina, delivered a highly interesting lecture on Thursday evening, at tbe Assembly Rooms, on " The American War and its Cause."
#Text=Harrington is a genuine Southerner, and of course his sympathies are with the Southerners.
#Text=He threw the whole blame of the war upon the Northerners, whom he protested would never subjugate the Southerners, who were fighting for what was dear to them—their liberty and independence.
